{{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = | name = Ameinias | honorific_suffix = | native_name = Ἀμεινίας | native_name_lang = Gr | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}} if dead--> | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} death date first, then birth date --> | birth_place = [[Pallini|Pallene]] or [[Decelea]] | death_place = | placeofburial = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | nickname = | birth_name = | allegiance = Athens | branch = | serviceyears = | rank = Trireme commander | servicenumber = <!--Do not use data from primary sources such as service records.--> | unit = | commands = | battles = {{bulleted list| [[Battle of Artemisium]] | [[Battle of Salamis]]}} | battles_label = | awards = Judged to have been the bravest (together with Eumenes) among all the Athenians at the battle of Salamis. | memorials = | spouse = <!-- Add spouse if reliably sourced --> | relations = {{unbulleted list| [[Aeschylus]] (brother) | [[Cynaegirus]] (brother) | Euphorion (father) |Philopatho (sister) | [[Philocles]] (nephew)}} | laterwork = | signature = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = }} '''Ameinias'''{{Pronunciation-needed}} or '''Aminias''' ({{lang-grc|Ἀμεινίας}}) was a younger brother of the playwright [[Aeschylus]] and a hero of the [[battle of Marathon]] [[Cynaegirus]]. He also had a sister, named Philopatho, who was the mother of the Athenian tragic poet [[Philocles]]. His father was Euphorion. Ameinias was from the [[Attica]] [[deme]] of [[Pallini|Pallene]] according to [[Herodotus]],<ref>[[Herodotus]], ''[[Histories (Herodotus)|Histories]]'' viii. 84, 93</ref> or of that of [[Decelea]] according to [[Plutarch]].<ref>[[Plutarch]], ''Themistocles'' 14</ref> He distinguished himself at the [[battle of Salamis]] as a [[Trireme]] commander, revenging the death of his brother [[Cynaegirus]] at [[battle of Marathon|Marathon]].
He made the first attack upon the [[Persia]]n ships (according to Athenians his ship made the first attack, but [[Aegina|Aeginetans]] said that one of their ships made the first attack), he also pursued the ship of [[Artemisia I of Caria|Artemisia]], and she rammed and sunk the ship of [[Damasithymos]] who was her ally to escape. When Ameinias saw that he thought that her ship was Greek and he changed the direction of his Trireme to chase other Persian ships.
Herodotus believed that Ameinias didn't know that Artemisia was on the ship, because otherwise he would not have ceased his pursuit until either he had captured her or had been captured himself, because orders had been given to the Athenian captains. Moreover, a prize had been offered of ten thousand [[drachmas]] for the man who should take her alive, since they thought it intolerable that a woman should lead an expedition against Athens.<ref>[http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/hh/hh8090.htm Herodotus Book 8: Urania, 93] "Now if he had known that Artemisia was sailing in this ship, he would not have ceased until either he had taken her or had been taken himself; for orders had been given to the Athenian captains, and moreover a prize was offered of ten thousand drachmas for the man who should take her alive; since they thought it intolerable that a woman should make an expedition against Athens."</ref>
In addition, according to Plutarch, he and the Socles of Pallene were the men who killed [[Ariabignes|Ariamenes]] (Herodotus says that his name was Ariabignes), brother of Xerxes and admiral of the Persian navy. When Ariamenes attempted to board on their ship, they hit him with their spears, and thrust him into the sea.<ref>[http://classics.mit.edu/Plutarch/themisto.html Themistocles By Plutarch] "Ariamenes, admiral to Xerxes, a brave man and by far the best and worthiest of the king's brothers, was seen throwing darts and shooting arrows from his huge galley, as from the walls of a castle. Aminias the Decelean and Sosicles the Pedian (''This is wrong translation his name was Socles and he was from Palene''), who sailed in the same vessel, upon the ships meeting stem to stem, and transfixing each the other with their brazen prows, so that they were fastened together, when Ariamenes attempted to board theirs, ran at him with their pikes, and thrust him into the sea..."</ref>
Ameinias and Eumenes of Anagyrus (Anagyrus is the modern [[Vari]]) were judged to have been the bravest on this occasion among all the Athenians.<ref>[[Diodorus Siculus]], ''[[Bibliotheca historica]]'' xi. 27</ref> [[Claudius Aelianus|Aelian]] mentions that Ameinias prevented the condemnation of his brother Aeschylus by the [[Areopagus]].<ref>[[Claudius Aelianus]], ''Varia Historia'' v. 19</ref><ref name="DGRBM">{{cite encyclopedia | last = Smith | first = William | authorlink = William Smith (lexicographer) | title = Ameinias | editor = [[William Smith (lexicographer)|William Smith]] | encyclopedia = [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]] | volume = 1 | pages = 141 | publisher = [[Little, Brown and Company]] | location = Boston | year = 1867 | url = http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/0150.html}}</ref>
